title: When will the CDC's novel coronavirus travel notice for China be lowered below "Warning - Level 3" and/or narrowed to cover only part of the country?
preds: Because there are only four more days and six days ago they were containing another outbreak in the Jilin province.
No indication that this will change. As usual, nothing is certain.
May 25 changed from 97% to 100% "Not before 1 June 2020"
2 recently new cases in China after a few days without any means the CDC probably won't lower it's warning level in the next week.

More likely that they narrow the travel notice than lower it below level 3. Quite likely that there will be no changes at this point but I will lower the 10% down to zero over the next two weeks unless there is some news that indicates otherwise.

Given the politicized scrutiny CDC is getting, the optics of lowering the China travel is is unneeded - President is actively promoting a narrative of confrontation, and US sentiment is mostly antagonistic

China has stabilised the outbreak. There are no new active cases generated in the country (source: https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/china/). Though, due to global reach of the virus (travel notice level 2) the risk of rapid infection into China could be looming. Even though I don't have benchmark data on how long travel notice information were held onto in past outbreaks, I would expect cautiousness and keep level 3 for China if the majority of the countries are still trying to contain the epidemic. Most countries will still have to deal with Covid-19 for 8 to 12 weeks.
China will be over any home grown infections of Covid19 by April 2020

It won't be lowered until a vacinne or antiviral is found. China will not accept international traveler for fear they bring Covid19 and it start all over again.
Graphs around the world are showing the legs to COVID19, while China's solution has been working - I believe they'll still avoid travelling.
I’m probably late to the party here, but the situation is stabilising in China pretty rapidly now. Now, being closer to 16 April, that 6 week window looks pretty likely.
China has tricked the world with wrong corona infections, as precaution it may take longer to setup the country as safe.

No new cases for a day but returning Chinese from places that have the virus could reignite. Admin might also not be in a hurry. Although Trump needs to get those Ag products flowing there to help his election.

The roles switched. The US now generates more deaths and cases a day than China.  But nevertheless so far CDC keeps a warning 3 for China. Does not make sense much from scientific point of view. Political, perceptions  - maybe.  But companies are already responding. Nike and Apple closed their stores in the US, but not in China. In a month, it may put pressure on CDC to follow science rather politics. Of course, COVID-19 may return to China. I put some probability to that as well.
With only 20 new cases a day and production in China ramping up this is likely to happen sooner than later.

Frankly China will continue its imposition of quarantine on all visitors but they may not show many cases outside of hubei. For now, it would seem that most of the cases to be reported by China in the coming weeks will be imported

Fewer reports of covid in China. Still, some sort of quarantine period is to be expected. As  there is a new found hypervigilance internationaly when it comes to preventive measures for disease spreading i Would estimate the waitingperiod for unexpected new rises in spreading up to 60 days. That puts us in mid May. I also think that more than 60 days Would start to stir up competing interest politicly. People hunkering down and starting to normalize the precribed avoidance behavior comes with it one costs. This is already clear if you look to the stockmarket.

Soon China will look as beacon of hope in the sea of trouble: in today's report, 11 new cases compared to 277 in the US. By the middle of May, it will be 42 days (3 incubation periods, usually required to determine the country infection-free) from the day of last infection (from my logistic model). So CDC, notwithstanding political considerations, will have no choice to downgrade the warning. If they exclude Hubei, it can be much earlier. It does not make sense already compared to the US. Of course, the COVID-19 can be reintroduced to China, with everything else going on in the world AND as they lift all barriers to commercial and social activity... But they got quite a system not to have that. Plus if SARS-CoV 2 is seasonal like other coronaviruses...

As @ jayb noted, new cases from China have dropped markedly. Anyone can see this from the WHO Situation Reports (https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/situation-reports/). Needless to say, I presume an abundance of caution on the part of the CDC and some level of political pressure. Furthermore, reducing the travel advisory would imply that China looks more like Japan, that is, has returned to some degree of normalcy. That does not seem likely in the near-term. We simply do not know enough to think that a return to normalcy would not trigger a fresh wave of nw cases. @Skildr points out that the SARS travel advisory lasted 96 days. In the link he shared (https://www.cdc.gov/about/history/sars/timeline.htm), the CDC says, "CDC lifted the travel alert on Toronto because more than 30 days (or three SARS incubation periods) had elapsed since the date of onset of symptoms for the last reported case", for its actions on May 20. For May 23: "CDC reinstated travel alert for Toronto because on May 22, Canadian health officials reported a cluster of five new probable SARS cases." I think a downgrading will demand a month or so of no new cases. China could achieve that within the next 30 days, giving the DCD 30 days from then to monitor the situation, so 60 days to be sure. So, let's say the first or second week of April is a good time to think the CDC might downgrade or lift the travel notice. However, though COVID-19 has a lower mortality rate than SARS (or MERS), it is transmitted between humans much more efficiently. For that reason, localizing it is very difficult so the CDC will be weary of a fresh wave of infections from China. Of course, China has much fewer rates of new cases than the UK and Western Europe, etc and in real as opposed to official figures, it is likely to have way fewer cases than the US, but I don't think that affects how the CDC will look at China. It makes sense to wait even if your home team is playing badly.

Guessing for now that some form of China ban stays in place for awhile, mainly out of 'caution'. Some narrowing does not seem out of the realm of possibility. U.S. is warning Americans about travelling abroad: https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/2020/03/12/coronavirus-state-department-warns-americans-reconsider-traveling-abroad/5029446002/ But virus cases are reportedly declining in China:
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-china/china-senior-medical-adviser-coronavirus-pandemic-over-by-june-if-countries-act-idUSKBN20Z046 https://fortune.com/2020/03/04/china-coronavirus-travel-restrictions/

After June 1 seems most likely. The SARS travel advisory lasted from Jan 27 to Jul 15 (96 days)
https://www.cdc.gov/about/history/sars/timeline.htm COVID-19 is more contagious. Jan 27 to Jun 1 is 126 days, so roughly a month longer.  Around 80,000 Chinese have Coronavirus, while a total of 8,300 contracted SARS, so it makes sense that the CDC will take longer to downgrade. CDC has changed its 'gradings' since SARS but Level 2 is basically exercise caution which based on the spread will be too lax in four months.

For some reason Japan is on the Level 2 list, but no EU countries- yet France, Germany and Spain have more than double the cases and higher death rates? These warnings seem incredibly arbitrary.

Even stranger as Taiwan has more new cases than China ex Hubei and Taiwan is not on the list of countries to avoid. So it will look strange for CDC to keep all of China under warning. With month to go in the 2nd bucket, I am moving some from the 3rd bucket to the 2nd. But CDC is supposed to be guided by data, rather than the latter.

Significant numbers of new cases outside Wuhan.

The daily infected cases in China have been crashing down from a peak of ~4k on 5 Feb to 331 on 28 Feb.  It looks like that the outbreak in China is under control.  That is if one can believe the numbers (which we have to assume to be correct for this forecast).  However, the daily infected cases could linger around a few hundreds for a while. To lower the travel warning level, CDC has to be confident about the reported cases.  The lack of transparency from the Chinese authority makes it difficult to be sure.  CDC will likely to act on the side of caution lest it gets the blame for introducing a large outbreak in the US.  Furthermore with the outbreak starting to happen outside China, it is possible that there is a secondary outbreak there in the future.   Three months from now is not too long considering how important the problem is.  I put this basket as the most likely time frame.
The last pandemic outbreak reached a peek at some moment and lowered quite fast after that

When will the CDC's novel coronavirus travel notice for China be lowered below "Warning - Level 3" and/or narrowed to cover only part of the country? The majority of new cases as of Feb 23 are still in Hubei. Assuming the warning would be narrowed first, then eliminated.

This is an update to my Feb. 8th forecast [see 1]. Base rate: As part of its response to the 2003 SARS outbreak, the CDC issued issued a travel alert for all of mainland China on March 29 and removed it on July 3 [2] - meaning the alert lasted for a total of 96 days. The CDC only lifted the travel alert once "more than 30 days (or three SARS incubation periods) had elapsed since the date of onset of symptoms for the last reported case" [2]. COVID-19: According to the CDC, the incubation period for COVID-19 is estimated to be anywhere between 2 and 14 days [3]. Assuming the CDC uses the 14 day number to be on the safe side, that would mean that the CDC would want to wait at least 42 days (three incubation periods) from the date of the last reported case before lifting its travel warning. The virus is still circulating in China and, while the daily reported case numbers are dropping, the epidemic in China may yet rebound once movement restrictions within the country are eased [4]. Moreover, there is widespread concern that China is under reporting its numbers due to either limited testing capacity, political pressures to keep reported case counts low - or both. -Before March 1: 0% chance of happening, given that there are only 8 days left until March 1.
-B/w March 1 and April 15: If the last reported case occurred today, the earliest possible date the CDC would lift the travel warning would be April 4 (42 days from now). However, the outbreak does not seem like it will end anytime soon - certainly not within the next eleven days, given the current number of cases being reported [5]. If the outbreak in China indeed lasts at least another eleven days, then that rules out a lowering of the travel notice before April 15. I will thus only assign a 1% probability to this bin.
-B/w April 16 and May 31: This will depend on how the outbreak plays out over the next few weeks. Tentatively, I will assign it a 13% chance.
-Not before June 1: 86% [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/964319
[2] https://www.cdc.gov/about/history/sars/timeline.htm
[3] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/symptoms.html
[4] https://www.statnews.com/2020/02/21/coronavirus-picking-up-steam-outside-china/
[5] My spreadsheet on COVID-19: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1d0JKwNcQsGVEMSMiUg0dZshGg-fVjWb7un-CNOi-vXk/edit?usp=sharing
The most likely condition is that the travel advisory will be narrowed to cover only part of China. Considering cases are stabilizing in China, this may occur within the next two months.

Sudden outburst in Shandong may tell that the Chinese are not quite in control outside Hubei. Or they just added confirmed cases from the past - impossible to say: the new cases were not even suspects yesterday. Decreasing probability of partial lifting of the Warning...

BNO Newsroom @BNODesk
1h
Nanjing, a major city in Jiangsu province, will ease restrictions after 2 days with no new cases of coronavirus. People will return to work, public places are reopening, and public transportation will resume.

With new warnings from major companies about loss of production and shortages due to the travel restrictions, the pressure will soon be on to get things moving in the parts of China that aren't seeing huge numbers of new cases/deaths.   For example, Beijing is a city of 22M+ people and currently has fewer than 400 cases and 4 deaths.   Shanghai has 24M and only 333 cases.  It makes sense for both China and the rest of the world to loosen the travel restrictions to these areas soon, to avoid unnecessary toll on the economy.  I don't see travel warnings getting better for Hubei or Guangdong anytime soon.

It all depends how CDC will treat China - one scenario - as a whole, another – to divide China into Hubei and everything else, or divide into groups of provinces - Hubei and provinces with high numbers of cases and the rest (at least 2 thirds of provinces including, importantly, Beijing).  By my logistic model, during the 3rd bucket. at this period ALL provinces including Hubei will reach 3 incubation periods without new infections, if installed preventive measures will hold up. Hence, I am placing most chances there.  If exclude Hubei, all other provinces will  reach this milestone right on the cusp of the 2nd bucket.  If CDC goes for the groups of provinces - limit its ban to provinces with ongoing outbreak – then 2nd bucket is possible as on April 10 by my model, Beijing and 22 other provinces will be free of new cases for 3 incubation periods.  Well, of course, all of that can be possible if the trend to outbreak containment will continue. But it looks China is hell bent in that happening. I will be watching how China clears its provinces from COVID-19. But so far it was following my model.

Economy will suffer if warning level 3 kept for too long
Numbers infected stabilising
Public aware of how virus is spread and will still take hygiene measures masks etc until no new cases arise
To be honest i think travel restrictions will be pointless after 15th April. It will be everywhere
The virus transfer ratio & long incubation rates make it unlikely that the CDC will re-evaluate it's guidance until cases are sub-1000
Likely to be dependent when temperatures increase in China.
Coronavirus likely to become endemic in China by June but possibly not in rest of world.
this will become a long term full year impact

When will the CDC's novel coronavirus travel notice for China be lowered below "Warning - Level 3" and/or narrowed to cover only part of the country? Given that the disease is still not completely characterized I am not optimistic for a rapid reduction in the warning.

A contrarian view. My model is holding up - by April 13, I expect all provinces except Hubei to be free of new cases for 3 incubation periods - a chance for CDC to downgrade. Of course, this will happen only if the preventive measures will hold up. Of course, CDC may keep its warning for just Hubei and a dozen other provinces and downgrade the alert for  two thirds of other provinces. That can happen even earlier than April 13.   The problem is that there is no sense of urgency in this political climate to do favors to the Chinese.  On the other hand, the Trump administration can use this as a sugar pill in trade negotiations. We'll see.

This is an update to my Feb. 8th forecast [see 1]. Base rate: As part of its response to the 2003 SARS outbreak, the CDC issued issued a travel alert for all of mainland China on March 29 and removed it on July 3 [2] - meaning the alert lasted for a total of 96 days. The CDC only lifted the travel alert once "more than 30 days (or three SARS incubation periods) had elapsed since the date of onset of symptoms for the last reported case" [2]. COVID-19: According to the CDC, the incubation period for COVID-19 is estimated to be anywhere between 2 and 14 days [3]. Assuming the CDC uses the 14 day number to be on the safe side, that would mean that the CDC would want to wait at least 42 days (three incubation periods) from the date of the last reported case before lifting its travel warning. The virus is still circulating and the epidemic shows no signs of abating as of yet - so the date of the last reported case will probably not come anytime soon. -Before March 1: 0% chance of happening, given that there are only 14 days left until March 1.
-B/w March 1 and April 15: If the last reported case occurred today (extremely unlikely), the earliest possible date the CDC would lift the travel warning would be March 31 (44 days from now). However, the outbreak does not seem like it will end anytime soon - certainly not within the next two weeks, given the current number of cases being reported [4]. If the outbreak indeed lasts at least another two weeks, then that rules out a lowering of the travel notice before April 15. I will thus only assign a 2% probability to this bin.
-B/w April 16 and May 31: This will depend on how the outbreak plays out over the next few weeks. Tentatively, I will assign it a 15% chance.

This forecast will require close attention to when/if active cases in some Chinese provinces begin to decline. Problem: we won't know when they begin to decline, only know when reports begin to decline. Another factor: President Trump is a germaphobe. So CDC may well be extra cautious about lifting the warning so as not to trigger Trump's wrath.

Two factors. One is the COVID-19 is retreating. Sure, it can break out, but right now in China it is retreating, with draconian measures in place.
Second is that Hubei province bears most of cases - 76%. The next province with 2nd highest number - Guangdong - has 2.7% (my estimates). So other provinces containing most of the population reach 0 cases/day earlier (not by much according to my model, but several days earlier) and the clock for 42 days (3x incubation period) should start ticking. My crude estimate is it might be around April 13, at the end of the 2nd bucket. Of course, instead CDC may want to wait to lift the warning for all China at once several days later... Putting more in the 2nd bucket at the expense of the last one... May revise it later, seeing how outbreak is contained in different provinces.
At some point it will become pointless; concessions will be made that the virus is out.
Update to take account of cases tailing off

The travel notice given for SARS was only released 3 months after it was first introduced and 2 months after number of new cases began meaningfully reducing. Given the Coronavirus has infected more people and has not yet peaked in terms of new cases which suggests a base case beyond mid-April for the travel ban to be reduced. I view it as pretty unlikely that the travel ban will be reduced before 15th April - this implies a more sanguine outcome than SARS - and view it as more likely that the travel ban is reduced after than 1 June than before given the outbreak's severity, plus the fact that beyond 1 June is open ended re timing.
Trump won't listen to the cdc , he wants China to owe him something before the elections.

The only reason I see for an earlier reduction would be natural spiking and protracted reporting of a decline in the number of new cases and deaths. I do not believe this will not come in the next three months

At the moment, the greatest fears about the coronavirus surround the speed of its spread and the unknown elements of how it can spread so easily. Part of this spread at the moment is facilitated by the season so that will improve as spring comes round and people stop spending so much time shut indoors together. As we learn more about the virus, in particular how it is spread and how it is best for individuals to protect themselves, we will probably see a relaxation in the travel ban. Not a complete relaxation – probably down to a level 2 – but enough to allow nonessential travel again.

I'm preparing for the worst and hoping for the best re Coronavirus. Based on what I have read, this is not a scenario with quick and easy solutions in the pipeline. However, trade and business will start to exert influence at some point and push for normalisation. Hebei region may be put off limits for much longer than these parameters.

2 week before 1st March, and this is the current quarantine time, so almost impossible before then, slim odds of them wanting to declare too early based on their ebola response, and distrust of official Chinese statistics

This forecast is based on the assumption that the CDC will be a bit conservative in lowering its travel warning. While on the ground circumstances may favor a lowering of the advisory in the 1 Mar–15 April 2020 period, the conservative approach of the CDC may delay the actual lowering to slightly later.

Adding a couple of general observations to those in forecasts below:  It's reportedly too early to definitively say if cases are 'leveling off. Still an "intense outbreak" in parts of China per W.H.O. Cases could accelerate again. (Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/02/08/world/asia/coronavirus-china.html) Experts, doctors etc. are still learning about the virus, including exactly how it spreads. (Source: https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/08/health/coronavirus-hospital-infections-frieden/index.html) FWIW: A couple of future, possible scenarios have been suggested for this version of Coronavirus, if not contained: It eventually (over 'a couple of years') may become somewhat 'milder' and may circulate as other known, 'common cold' coronaviruses presently do. Or, possibly: "2019-nCoV returns repeatedly like a bad seasonal flu". 
(Source: https://www.statnews.com/2020/02/04/two-scenarios-if-new-coronavirus-isnt-contained/) Given that no tested vaccine is expected to be available at least before June 1 (..likely longer: https://www.staradvertiser.com/2020/02/06/breaking-news/experts-scramble-but-new-coronavirus-vaccine-may-not-come-in-time/), it currently doesn't appear to be a very 'promising' scenario for early lifting of CDC's travel notice. As noted below it took over 90 days to lift such a ban for the SARS outbreak -- which eventually was contained via global cooperation including quarantines, travel restrictions and other measures.

Base rate: As part of its response to the 2003 SARS outbreak, the CDC issued issued a travel alert for all of mainland China on March 29 and removed it on July 3 [1] - meaning the alert lasted for a total of 96 days. The CDC only lifted the travel alert once "more than 30 days (or three SARS incubation periods) had elapsed since the date of onset of symptoms for the last reported case" [1]. 2019-nCoV: According to the CDC, the incubation period for the circulating 2019-nCoV virus is estimated to be anywhere between 2 and 14 days [2]. Assuming the CDC uses the 14 day number to be on the safe side, that would mean that the CDC would want to wait at least 42 days (three incubation periods) from the date of the last reported case before lifting its travel warning. The virus is still circulating and the epidemic shows no signs of abating as of yet - so the date of the last reported case will probably not come anytime soon. -Before March 1: 0% chance of happening, given that there are only 21 days left in the month.
-B/w March 1 and April 15: If the last reported case occurred today (extremely unlikely),  the earliest possible date the CDC would lift the travel warning would be March 23 (44 days from now). However, the outbreak does not seem like it will end anytime soon - certainly not within the next two weeks, given the current number of cases being reported [3]. I will only assign a 4% probability to this bin.
-B/w April 16 and May 31: This will depend on how the outbreak plays out over the next few weeks. Tentatively, I will assign it a 20% chance.
-Not before June 1: 76% [1] https://www.cdc.gov/about/history/sars/timeline.htm
[2] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/about/symptoms.html
[3] My spreadsheet on 2019-nCoV: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1d0JKwNcQsGVEMSMiUg0dZshGg-fVjWb7un-CNOi-vXk/edit?usp=sharing

"Level 4 – Do Not Travel" is in force, since the life threating conditions are still ongoing in China. The biggest driver is the growthrate of the Corona virus. Forinstance, The Modern Plague began in the 1860s and killed more than 12 million people in China, India and Hong Kong. It wasn’t until the 1890s that people figured out how the bacterial infection was being spread and a vaccine was created. Scientists declare how Corona virus being spread, but it is known that when the vaccine is available. Therefore, it is likely that the vaccine will take years to be developed. But it is not the only way to stop a virus such as MERS, SARS and EBOLA. So, it is likely that in 6 months, disease will stop and decrease in spreading rates.

@chwang has a good comment on this.  The first bucket should be zero as of today, and the second is extremely unlikely in my opinion.  As for the other two, sticking with 3 incubation periods before lifting the travel notice would mean the last case would have to be mid-to-late April for the "Not before 1 June 2020" threshold.  That's a big maybe based on the SARS timeline and assuming Corona started in mid December. Revisit at the end of Feb.

During the 2003 SARS epidemic, the CDC did not lift its travel ban on Toronto until there were no more reported cases with symptoms for 3 incubation periods. The incubation time is currently as long as 2 weeks. Therefore, the CDC is unlikely to lift the ban to China until 6 weeks after the last case. Given the current state of uncertainty including probable under-diagnosis of the true prevalence, I suspect the China epidemic of nCoV will continue for at least 3 months. Thus, plus the 6 week monitoring period, makes late May the earliest a travel ban would be lifted. But this likelihood is low.
